channel.title: Best Storage Methods
channel.description: I was just wondering, what is the best Storage method, for a basically 2 dimensional array? IM trying to stop using fixed size arrays, like int[][]'s and such. But for something similar, but more efficient, what would i use? Like a Hashtable, or hashmap, or something like that?

item.title: Best Storage Methods
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Killer-99-pkz, post:47, topic:254627”]Ok do you know why they made to lists run the same, LinkedList and ArrayList, if what you say is true the have the same purpose.
[br][br][size=1]Posted on: January 24, 2009, 03:56:28 pm[/size][hr]oh heheh i was looking at jdk version 6.3’s source of java.util.ArrayList which doesent expand automaticly.[/quote]

First question:
They both implement the List interface, which is the purpose of inheritance, to your program they do run the same, the underlying implementation is very different though, which makes one or the other more appropriate for a particular application, because different methods, add, get, set (and others) take different amounts of time to complete. You need to learn about the different types of data structures to make the best choices in your programs

Second:
I think all java.util.ArrayList’s expand automatically.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Storage Methods
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“shangtsung1, post:44, topic:254627”]ArrayList list = new ArrayList(1);

remove that 1 and it expands by itself fine :S[/quote]

It should expand fine regardless. Though there is almost no point in setting the initial size to 1, as then you have to use more processing power to have it expand many times before even getting to the original default of 10.

Read full topic

}[/code]

item.title: Best Storage Methods
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Killer-99-pkz:

An ArrayList has to be manualy expanded. I know from personal experience to expand it you use the method “ensureCapacity(Integer minCapacity)” (if (capacity < minCapacity) resize ArrayList…) so it saves your memory bank unless you trim the list down to size using “trim()”.

    /**
     * Appends the specified element to the end of this list.
     *
     * @param e element to be appended to this list
     * @return <tt>true</tt> (as specified by {@link Collection#add})
     */
    public boolean add(E e) {
	ensureCapacity(size + 1);  // Increments modCount!!
	elementData[size++] = e;
	return true;
    }
    /**
     * Increases the capacity of this <tt>ArrayList</tt> instance, if
     * necessary, to ensure that it can hold at least the number of elements
     * specified by the minimum capacity argument.
     *
     * @param   minCapacity   the desired minimum capacity
     */
    public void ensureCapacity(int minCapacity) {
	modCount++;
	int oldCapacity = elementData.length;
	if (minCapacity > oldCapacity) {
	    Object oldData[] = elementData;
	    int newCapacity = (oldCapacity * 3)/2 + 1;
    	    if (newCapacity < minCapacity)
		newCapacity = minCapacity;
            // minCapacity is usually close to size, so this is a win:
            elementData = Arrays.copyOf(elementData, newCapacity);
	}
    }

'Nuff said?

Read full topic

item.title: Best Storage Methods
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Killer-99-pkz:

An ArrayList has to be manualy expanded. I know from personal experience to expand it you use the method “ensureCapacity(Integer minCapacity)” (if (capacity < minCapacity) resize ArrayList…) so it saves your memory bank unless you trim the list down to size using “trim()”.

An ArrayList does not need to be expanded manually, that method is there for speed reasons.

Read full topic

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html[/quote]

item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ya, i was thinking of loading the information from a MySQL database. 3 Columns, Client Version, Packet ID, and Packet Description. Something like:

Manager.query = "SELECT * FROM PacketInfo";
List<Integer> ClientVersions = Manager.getResults(1);
List<Integer> PacketIDs = Manager.getResults(2);
List<String> PacketDesc = Manager.getResults(3);

Read full topic

item.title: Best Storage Methods
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:27, topic:254627”]If i were doing commands, i wouldn’t be able to use a switch anyways. Java doesn’t support Strings in switch statements. I am working on a polymorphic-server. 317, 474, 503, 508 and 523 clients will be able to connect to it, by reading what version the client is, (outer cases), then loading the packets that way(Inner cases). SOmething like this:

switch(ClientID) {
    case 317:
        switch(PacketID) {
            case 53://Item On Item
                ...
            break;
        }
    break;
    ...
}

But there is also another reason. I was going to try to make a bot that used something like this. I know server questions are for moparscape, but 80% of the people there wouldn’t know how to do this at all.[/quote]
That’s a stupid way of doing it. You should load the packet id’s dynamically from a file depending on the client version.

Read full topic

item.title: Best Storage Methods
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

If i were doing commands, i wouldn’t be able to use a switch anyways. Java doesn’t support Strings in switch statements. I am working on a polymorphic-server. 317, 474, 503, 508 and 523 clients will be able to connect to it, by reading what version the client is, (outer cases), then loading the packets that way(Inner cases). SOmething like this:

switch(ClientID) {
    case 317:
        switch(PacketID) {
            case 53://Item On Item
                ...
            break;
        }
    break;
    ...
}

But there is also another reason. I was going to try to make a bot that used something like this. I know server questions are for moparscape, but 80% of the people there wouldn’t know how to do this at all.

Read full topic
